reviewText: I have seen some of DB's performances on TV and video before (never have had the lucky chance of seeing him live) and the past couple of live performances I have seen DB on TV have been very good.. I mean stellar.So, I made my mind up that I was going to wait until a new DB Live DVD came out so I could at least hear the most recent (and wonderful) band backing him.. and lets face it, DB has had  various, different, lineups behind him the past 15 years... some very good, some very 'different' but all DB.When I saw this particular DVD, I grabbed it and it is really a great package.  I got it for under 10 bucks (Target anyone?) and the songs sound great (I won't go into each song since there are a ton of them) but the band really is great and DB sounds fantastic.The reason for writing this review is simple... DB has been around a long time, and if you want an older package of him, go get a different DVD, this is of his most recent tour, with most recent band.  If you have some older DVD's of DB and want a newer one of him performing some of his newer material (heathen/newkillerstar/reality are done fantastically) this is the DVD for you.And lets face it... you get a 30 song DVD for under 10 bucks?  Where can you do that?One note, MAN WHO SOLD THE WORLD is done wonderfully, and DB had not done this song live for quite some time.  It sounds just superb.Have Fun!
summary: A very intimate setting.. and great sound

reviewText: I am a Bowie "fanatic" since I was 13, so i might be a little"biased". I saw David Bowie at the Benedum Center in Pittsburgh,Pa, and it probably was the BEST concert I have been to in a long time! I agree with some of the previous reviewers,Bowie easily performed like a man half his age, the DVD gives you a "hint" of that, being there "live" was  BEST!This DVD is a great memento of a great tour, by a guy who really is AWESOME in concert. My only criticism is not getting "Queen Bitch" as one of the songs included, or "Station to Station", butI still LOVE IT!  Thanks David!
summary: A Great Memento From A Great Tour
Title: N/A

reviewText: Certainly an adequate DVD, capturing a nearly 2 1/2 hour performance on David Bowie's latest tour. Like others who reviewed the DVD on Amazon, I caught this tour (the Philadelphia show that had been canceled due to Bowie's illness with the flu and later added to the end of the tour.) This is a different set than he played at the Philly show, in which I had hoped he'd play more of his late '70s period work. Though there isn't much of that here, he does play "Sister Midnight," "Be My Wife," and the absolute stunner "Heroes." It's a great show, and I'm happy to have it on DVD. (And have you noticed that the price is dirt cheap by DVD standards?) The extra feature of being able to program the order in which you can play up to 7 songs is pretty cool, as well. His career has produced so many great songs that some are simply bound to be missing no matter what you do, so don't sweat it that he doesn't play "China Girl" or "Golden Years." I'm a David Bowie fan and I like this DVD very much. If you like the span of his career, from "The Man Who Sold the World" and "Ziggy Stardust" to "Heathen" and "Reality," you'll like it too.
Title: N/A

America we get nothign but close-ups with the occasional quick glance at the animated kids break dancing. What a waste.

reviewText: I missed the show in Tokyo and have been kicking myself ever since. Thankfully, this DVD provides enough of an "experience" to absolve me of my sin. In a nutshell, a fantastic tour with David at his best backed up by a great band but shot in psychotic fashion.I've always loved Bowie's alter-personas, in particular the Thin White Duke, but here we have David Bowie as himself, if that's possible. He's laid back, relaxed, and delivers a knock-out performance. He's like a kid in a candy store and enjoying every minute. It's also remarkable that his voice and vocal range are still intact when so many others of his generation have lost that ability. Listen to Five Years with your eyes closed and you would swear that Ziggy Stardust is alive and well.In an age where true, live performances seem to be an exception rather than the norm, many young artists could learn from this and realize that it takes hard work and practice to deliver Live. Yes, it's harder than lip synching or singing to a background track. And what a great band it is: Mike Garson (keyboards), Sterling Campbell (drums), Catherine Russell (keyboards, guitar, vocals), Gail Ann Dorsey (Bass & vocals), Earl Slick & Gerry Leonard (guitars). This band is tight and gifted. Bowie, already renowned for his selection of musicians for tours and albums, has again assembled a primo supporting cast.My favorites: Heroes, Cactus, Fantastic Voyage (beautiful), I'm Afraid of Americans, Ashes to Ashes (very interesting guitar by Monsieur Slick), Life on Mars, and especially Under Pressure where Bowie duets with Gail Ann Dorsey. Wow, I never knew who Gail was but I certainly do now. What a talent she is. One of the best renditions I've ever heard and it's live!!If it weren't for the fragmented editing and "special effects" which are more annoying than accentual, this would be a no-brainer Five Stars. You can bet that I won't make the same mistake twice next time Bowie comes to town.
summary: Professional & Emotive Show but Psychotic Filming.

reviewText: This is a great performance DVD that captures a single show from Bowie and his band prior to his run in with heart trouble.  For the most part it's a first-class presentation and and engaging performance.  The big problem?  The songs.  It's true Bowie has a massive collection to choose from, but why do I find myself pining for a dose of "Diamond Dogs" or "Let's Dance" or even one day perhaps "Golden Years" over some of his more recent pedestrian work. It's a nice package, but for me it's a one-time event and I'll probably never watch it again.
summary: Good DVD, Too Bad About The Songs
Title: N/A

reviewText: Wow, double wow and triple wow. Having been a fan of this man since first seeing him at the Boston Music Hall in 1972 when he only filled half the seats, I'm totally BLOWN AWAY by this DVD and couldn't offer a negative word about it. The only way it could be improved would be if it was in 3D and Julie Christie was sitting on my lap. My most intense rock rush of all time was seeing Bowie at Radio City Music Hall in 73, as Aladdin Sane. When he and the Spiders opened with a ferocious, high flying "Hang On To Yourself" it just took the top of my head off. Well, this show, live, hit that peak about ten times in the course of the evening. This DVD transmits the excitement of a live show like very few are able to do. Beyond Bowie himself, his incredible, incredible band is something to behold, the best he's ever had. The material is exceptional, a beautfully balanced song list, great audio, great camerawork, great editing, and a wild audience that's totally plugged in. You either get Bowie or you don't. This audience gets it, and fuels him. What's particularly satisfying is that the performance gives blood and beauty to some of Bowie's recent songs which may have been less that satisfying on CD. All in all, you've got to bow down to the magnitude of this guy's artistic accomplishment and credibility. Rock for smart people, rock as art. A two hour shot of adrenaline, a STUNNING video experience.

reviewText: Having seen the first of his two Melbourne shows I've been waiting with baited breath for the DVD release of this concert. Never would I have believed, even as a veteran Bowie fan, that the guy who's pushing 60 could get up on stage and sound that good, perform that well and look so damn cool!By all means treat yourself to this disc, even if you only have a mild interest in the man and his music you'll love it and be converted forever.

reviewText: After reading the disappointed-fan review of this DVD labeling it as unbearably artsy and MTV-cliched I was apprehensive to make the purchase.  However, perhaps because the reviewer was actually fortunate enough to beat the concert and s/he is making comparisons of which I have none (aside from my first concert ever - Bowie 1978!), I was enthralled with this DVD.  Yes, it isn't straight shot concert footage, there is enhancement here and there with some 'artsy' stuff, but not much; certainly not enough to detract from the enjoyment of the performance and the music.I didn't read the set list before I bought the disc; I wanted to be "surprised," like a concert-goer (call me a dork).  It rocked.  The set was long, fabulously and energetically performed, and everyone seemed to be rocking out having a great time.  Bowie, older for sure, but still beautiful, flashing smile, playing and having fun with the audience, voice incredible, absolutely INCREDIBLE as always.  He's amazing.  When they performed "Under Pressure," Gail Ann Dorsey floored me with her range and strength of voice.  I never heard her really do a lead vocal, I guess.Additionally, the number of old favourites was staggering and really made the entire show an event.  The opening with classic Bowie, interspersal of classic Bowie amongst all of the newer works, and the closing with classic culminating in a terrific performance of "Ziggy Stardust" just had me cheering on my sofa like I was there.  Dork, as I said.  I think "my kids" need to see this, and I'm trying to figure out how to incorporate it legitimately into middle school math curriculum!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Of the hundreds of live acts that I've seen since the early 70's, Bowie in New Orleans '04 was in the top 10.  Sadly, this DVD does not do justice to the show.  It's edited badly:  very much in the MTV-attention deficit disorder-herky jerky syle.  It's good, (it's Bowie in fine form after all) but it should have been one of the greatest concert films of all time.  The ability to mix 7 songs in any order is nice; but the menu itself loops Rebel Rebel in the most annoyingly loud way imaginable (note to editors: menu music should never be louder than the movie!).  Even the remarkable duet on Under Pressure with Gail Ann Dorsey is visually ruined by the worst video edit on the DVD.  The tour was 5 stars and Bowie's voice was terrific.  The 5.1 mix is 4 stars; but the visual editing is 2 stars.  I think overall it's a 3.5 star film but I'll round up to 4.  Sorry to point out the negative aspects, so to end on the positives: it's very attractively priced and an order of magnitude better than the average concert film.
summary: Well, it was a great tour.  DVD is a bit of a letdown

Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm very mixed on this one.  I'm a huge Bowie fan and was excited by the mix of songs, including the Iggy Pop classic, Sister Midnight.  Bowie is still looking great and has a certain ease on stage.  As other reviewers have pointed out, it is well-produced.  But the problem for me is that it is so highly produced that it ends up being kind of dull to watch.  Tons of post-production went into this (maybe that's where it happened), and you even get the idea that they asked the audience to do a bunch of stock responses that they layered in.  It affects the musical performance too - it's just too clean and doesn't have much of a personality to it - like they doused this one with antiseptic.  Novel to see for Bowie fans, but I am disappointed and am going to sell my copy.  He just didn't need all this cliche stuff - he's got enough charisma on his own.  Too bad.
summary: Too much post production, and not enough charisma.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm a latecomer to much of David Bowie's brillance.  My wife has been a fan much longer than I have.  My previous exposure had been his hits on the radio such as "Changes", "Young Americans" and the like, then my first album purchase of his music was the more commercial "Let's Dance".  I had also been exposed to him through his collaboration with Pat Metheny on "This is Not America" (I'm a big Metheny fan), onto Tin Machine and the like.  Still, I was not aware of him a performer.  I didn't even know until a few years ago that he had written the hit, "All the Young Dudes".I think what lit me up was learning (Don't laugh!) that Vanilla Ice's "Ice Baby" or whatever that song was had a riff which was lifted from "Under Pressure".  I started checking out vides of this on YouTube and came across the extraordinary performance from this show with Gail Ann Dorsey, whom I previously knew through her touring in Dar Williams (and doing a solo turn on Williams great live album, "Out There Live".).  My interest also piqued after I had learned that he had wanted to be a cabaret artist (I had done a bit of this myself.).  I started to see how he connects himself to the lyric of the song, at least with most performances.  He was a real performance artist.  I tended to like performers who connected themselves with their music in this way.  Peter Gabriel is another that comes to mind.I started to check out different video concerts of his and this one got generally very good reviews.  I decided to order this and "Ziggy Stardust:  The Motion Picture", a concert documentary by the famed documentarian D.A. Pennebaker.  BTW, I will also put up a review of that one.Meanwhile, as someone else lamented, the filmmakers left out much of Bowie's patter, and according to that poster, this is part of the charm of his more recent shows.  My wife saw the "Serious Moonlight Tour" and told me that he was constantly looking at his watch and did not do much in the way of patter.  In any event, as we watched this DVD, she was quite impressed with how generous the set list was.  She also complained that she wish it had more songs she was familiar with.  She largely liked the older rock and roll stuff.My take on the concert itself is, again, it was quite entertaining, having not heard or seen him before live (aside from viewing the Ziggy Stardust movie a week or so before seeing this one.).  Sometimes the performances ventured into being extraordinary.  Even some of his new songs, to me, were great, "Slip Away" from "Heathen" being one of them.  Some of the songs got great reworkings.  "Fame" got slowed down and funked up.  "Ashes to Ashes" got almost the acoustic treatment, reaaly quite stripped down and was absolutely haunting.I really never felt, unlike a couple of posters, that Bowie and the band mailed it in, or were simply crowd-pleasing.  "All the Young Dudes" was treated as an anthem, complete with audience singalong, rather than as a statement.  But most of the songs seemed to have Bowie serious with the lyric.  I will say, on the other hand, the concert didn't have the absolute energy and rawness evident in the "Ziggy Stardust" performance.  But he was far from mailing it in.  I thought the band was extraordinary.  Overall, it's a really well-worthwhile DVD concert video to see and own.  No interesting extras, per se, but there is an interesting feature where you can program up to 7 songs to play in any order you wish.Regarding the technical aspects of the DVD, I'll start with the visuals.  All of the posts on YouTube of selections of this DVD showed a 4:3 aspect ration, so it surprised me that this was in 16:9.  Not a big deal either way, it just surprised me.  The director of this DVD, as some others have pointed out, must have been much too hyped up on caffeine or some other stimulant.  Particularly for the first half of the concert, the images jump around sometimes a bit too much, other times much too much, and occasionally laden with digital effects.  I'm guessing, with regard to the latter, the director chose to use the visuals that were put up on the large screens above and at the rear of the stage rather than just letting us see it direct.  Note to the director:  Must viewing -- Jonathan Demme's "Stop Making Sense".Sonically, unfortunately, I had recently watched the "Ziggy Stardust" DVD and that film is about as good as it gets, sonically speaking.  If you want to hear a DVD concert film that has the balance of good analog and allows the full dynamics of the music to come out, check out that film.  Cymbals on that soundtrack sound rich, reverberant and real rather thin, tinny and sibilant as they do on the "Reality Tour" video.  The "Ziggy Stardust" film could be a demo for your hifi system.  I have a really good analog setup and whenever I put records on after hearing most commercially produced CDs, I realize what music should really sound like.  At least a well-produced LP on a good turntable gets you much farther towards real music.  The "Reality Tour" DVD soundtrack can just get bright, grainy, thick and compressed during denser rock passages.  On the other hand, during quieter moments, such as "Bring Me the Disco King" or "Ashes to Ashes", the mastering engineer allows the sound to open up.  Part of the problem is the Dolby-processed soundtrack of "Reality Tour" vs. the PCM stereo of the "Ziggy Stardust" film (I get excited when I see a PCM stereo option).Anyway, I do much recommend this DVD, even with a few flaws.  On the other hand, I jump and down enthusiastically for the "Ziggy Stardust" film.
summary: Very Entertaining Concert, Though Some Obscure Songs For Me
Title: N/A

reviewText: I too saw this exceptionally brillant show "Reality" when ittoured through the Boston area and this DVD captures so manyof the highlights. Artsy, yeah, that for sure but that is alwaysthe way Bowie presented himself right from the start. I wouldexpect nothing less from him but there are so many standout performances here and so much detail through out, its a greatdeal for the money and vital to his history through out the70's, 80's, 90's and well into the 21st century. Bowie is myhero in terms of his ageless, musical genius, he just keepsrolling them out. Like my other favorite female counterpart,Bonnie Raitt, they have kept themselves going constantlyshifting into both new territories and always giving fans a taste of their past. They both look great and are making someof the best music of their careers, still in their 50's????"Reality" the dvd has some key songs "Under pressure" with Gail Dorsey is such a blast, right on the moneyand gives this song new life. "I'm afraid of Americans" is another hidden jewel that gets a really rocking edge thatsmesmerizing in concert. The artsy ones, "The lonelist guy","The Motel", "Sunday", "Heathen", to name some of them are all done evenbetter than on record, the cut against the rock of "New killerstar", "Hallo spaceboy", and the pop nuggets, "Fame", "Heros","Ashes to Ashes", and classic sounds of "Rebel Rebel", "ZiggyStardust" this is a well mixed show. I miss the song "Lets Dance" because it made such an impact on the concert I saw, theway he came out onto a platform and danced the night away, itis missed here but with such a back catalogue of songs, itsreally personal preference. Bowie, as he inches ever near thebig 60 shows that its not about age, when you're a true showmenyou can just go on and on, your fans will always travel withyou through lifes journey, lets hope David Bowie continues withhis excellent music. One of the best concert shows of the year!
Title: N/A

reviewText: David Bowie has been putting out some great albums in the last decade (_Earthling_, _Heathen_, and _Reality_) and this DVD is a nice snapshot of his current touring band.  The new songs such as "New Killer Star," "Never Get Old," "Sunday," and "I'm Afraid of Americans," can all stand comfortably aside the classics ("Changes," "Fame," "Under Pressure," etc.).  The sound is excellent and it is really a joy to see Bowie having so much fun.  The band that he's been touring with these past few years is fantastic (even if Reeves Gabriel isn't part of it).  The only thing I wish this DVD had are some extra features (perhaps some behind-the-scenes footage or interviews with Bowie and the band), but at less than $15, you'll definitely get your money's worth from the full-length concert performance alone.  Well worth the money if you're a Bowie fan, and well worth buying if you are a casual fan that wants to see what Bowie is like in a live setting.
summary: Nice Modern Snapshot of Bowie Live

reviewText: Michael Thomas Roe's comments are bang on.This is a great concert spoiled by a director with ADD. And the sound isn't that good either: both the stereo mix and the 5.1 seemed a little muddy to me.But if you always meant to see a Bowie concert and never got around to it, this is the DVD for you.  Inspite of it's "faults" it still shows a master at work.I loved every minute.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Some of Bowie's DVD concerts are good and some are great.  This is one of the great ones.  Remixed into 5.1 Surround Sound, the audio is amazingly crisp and clear.  The light show is blinding in some cases (as was the actual show in person) and the director/editors use this to their advantage in splicing scenes.  Some of the special effects (freeze-frame, reverse imaging, blurs, etc.) can get tedious, but it doesn't hurt the overall feel of the concert.  Each band member gets plenty of close-ups and the backing vocals are near perfect.  After nearly two years on the road, Bowie has connected to his audience like never before, losing any pretension.  He's there to have a good time.With nearly 60 songs used throughout the tour, it's tough to settle on which 30 Bowie decided to use, but the variety is great.  "Quicksand" and "Let's Dance" were, unfortunately, not used, but some of the stand-out cuts were the incredible audience sing-along, "All The Young Dudes", the hard, fast romping of, "Hang On To Yourself" and "Under Pressure" where bassist Gail Ann Dorsey seems to channel Freddie Mercury's voice.  It's eerie and wonderful!  The box itself is disappointing, in that it is thin cardboard and the insert gives little information about the tour.  I would have liked to know the concert song lists and the cities played.  If that's all I can find wrong with this set, I'd say Bowie delivered a prized concert DVD.  Did I mention its incredibly low priced?
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was one of the many who saw the "Reality" tour and was mightily impressed.  I had never seen Bowie so close up, nor so spirited and "alive".  So it's a pleasure to have the "magic" captured on this DVD.  It serves as a nice souvenir and is more than reasonably priced.So what's wrong with it?  Well, it's unbearably "artsy".  Every MTV-inspired cliché is in full swing.  Jump cuts, freeze frames, fades to black, fades to white, colorizations, negative images, upside down images, crazy camera angles.  You name it.  And I can't believe that this is even an issue, but there is an amazing lack of sustained close ups and images of Bowie, the man himself.  One almost thinks that the director or editor had some kind of beef with Bowie.  When it comes time for Bowie to hit home with one of his lyrical and poignant lines, say from "Loving the Alien" or "Fantastic Voyage", the image is of a keyboardist's hand or a smiling audience member, or bass player Gail Ann Dorsey, on whom the director or editor seem to have some kind of fixation.  It's all very curious.There is more expression in Bowie's eyes, posture and hand gestures than any jump cut, freeze frame or artsy device "to keep things interesting".  What a pity.  This is clearly a missed opportunity.
Title: N/A

reviewText: My brother-in-law recently picked up this DVD. We'd all seen Bowie in the past, but this show was better than our live experiences. (Admittedly they were many years ago.) With The Reality Tour, he was able to take a life time of music, style and personas and meld them into a portfolio filled with energy and innovation. We were captivated by "The Lonliest Guy", "Under Pressure" and "Cactus" and I cannot get "Rebel Rebel" out of my head. Suffice to say this DVD rekindled our collective interest in David Bowie, who even after all these years retains an air of obscurity and mystery. Such a rare & lovely thing these days.

reviewText: For casual Bowie fans, this is one juicy whopper to chew on. A staggering 30 songs are performed here.A Reality Tour is about promoting the Reality album. So unsurprisingly, about 10 numbers including New Killer Star and Reality are given an airing. If you like Heathen, the title track and Slip Away are yours to savour.This DVD is not about the commercial Bowie. So Let's Dance, Dancing In The Streets and Absolute Beginners are omitted. The most accessible stuff are Rebel Rebel, Under Pressure and Ashes To AshesI was quite blown away by the rock version of Hallo Spaceboy, very different from the Pet Shop Boys'. The arrangement on Loving The Alien is also stellar, making the track sound more alien and 'spacey'.Three tracks are cut from the DVD but are included in the Live CD. They are Fall Dog Bombs The Moon, Breaking Glass and China Girl. Nice try Sony, to sell more CDs.
Title: N/A

reviewText: ...Minus two stars for delivery and overall feeling. Even after being put off by the obviously nipped & tucked/airbrushed Ralph-Lauren Polo ads and the somewhat Never Let Me Down-era Bowie that is among us right now, I still decided to pick up the Reality Tour dvd just because it has tracks like Fame, Sister Midnight, Fantastic Voyage, The Motel, Life On Mars, Be My Wife and All The Young Dudes. The disappointment is that the songs feel kinda hollow and half-hearted. Yes, everyone is playing spectacularly, but it wouldn't make a difference if robots were in their place. There is an insincerity in Bowie's performance from the way he carefully looks over his shoulder at the crowd to the way he carefully points to the crowd to the way he carefully touches his face, all carefully done in order to look just perfectly so. this, in turn, makes everything seem awkward, staged, laboured and just not very spontaneous/real. everything is so cautious and calculated. i was kinda disappointed that there were no Station To Station songs on the setlist, but then after watching it i don't think i could have bared a watered-down and carefully paced version of Golden Years or TVC15. The fact that they keep cutting to Mike Garson's sheet-music LCD screen keeps reminding me that everything and everyone one on stage is probably synced thru Pro Tools or Logic and every sound is tweaked just so so that everything is clean and audible and everything that's supposed to be distorted and noisy isn't too distorted and noisy, i.e. nothing is left to glorious and wonderful chance. the amount of control and processing just sucks the life out of the songs. God forbid anything real or spontaneous to happen. and i know that when musicians play live the audience expects to hear the songs from the albums, note-for-note, but this is just sad. it's kind of ironic that he made Low, embracing technology & experimenting, adding a detatched iciness to pop and rock only to later embrace technology and become totally detatched from the music. i don't even connect today's Bowie with the 1978 Bowie who sang 'Heroes', and this dvd sadly reinforces that sentiment. and the video sequences are so boring and generic(like car commercials?). i thought Bowie was an engaging artist. where are the challenging visuals?trust me, this is all coming froma huge Bowie fan. no one was more revelatory to me than Bowie. But now he comes off just as processed as Avril or Ashlee Simpson. it's probably the modus operendi of the music industry now, but still depressing all the same. I will say, though, Fame is interestingly updated and Life On Mars? and Bring Me The Disco King have hints of humanity about them...but they're *just* hints(and fleeting at that).I bought this DVD purely for the tracklist. Casual fans of Bowie might enjoy this for the "what's-he-up-to" factor, but hardcore fans should just stick with the Ziggy Stardust Movie and the Best Of Bowie videos until Stage and Live are released in the next month or so. It's a good thing A Reality Tour is priced less that $20 because it's really not worth more than $25 or $30.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was a tour of surprises, and they're all captured here on this terrific DVD.Okay, first the obligatory: Bowie looks and sounds terrific.  The band is fantastic.  The stage set is pretty cool.But the real star of this show is the song list.  This is Bowie celebrating and revelling in an impressive and important career.There are equally as many surprising ommisions as their are inclusions.  For instance, there's no "Let's Dance", "Jean Genie", "Suffragette City", etc.  But the surprises we DO get include "Be My Wife", a haunting version of "The Motel", a gripping acoustic rendition of "Loving the Alien", and a superb version of the Bowie/Pop classic "Sister Midnight".The show opens with the new arrangment of "Rebel Rebel", followed quickly by "New Killer Star" and the smokin' "Reality", definitely one of the highlights of the show.  Other highlights include the modern Bowie masterpiece "Sunday" with Earl Slick's wonderful but far-too-short guitar solo, a rousing "Man Who Sold the World", the audience sing-along of "Life on Mars?", the very clever pairing of "Never Get Old" with "Changes", and of course Gail Ann Dorsey singing and playing the hell out of "Under Pressure."  We're also treated to concert staples like "Fame", "I'm Afraid of Americans", and "Hallo Spaceboy".The biggest and best highlight for me, though, comes at the end: the concert draws to a close with "Heroes", which starts out very quiet and minimal, and then slowly builds throughout the song, all gearing up to a powerful, inspiring, and yes, 'heroic' ending.  Its an amazing arrangement of an amazing song, and could last a couple minutes longer in my opinion, but is unfortunately truncated a bit.After a short break, the band retakes the stage for an incredible 6-song encore, divided evenly into 2 3-song sets.  The first set is comprised of three of his recent moodier, more atmospheric pieces.  First is the wonderful "Bring Me the Disco King", one of the true highlights of the REALITY album, and featuring the brilliant Mike Garson on piano.  This is followed by "Slip Away" (I must be the only Bowie fan that doesn't like that song!) and a terrific reading of "Heathen".  The band then kicks open the old-school throttle for "Five Years", "Hang on to Yourself" and the king-daddy of all Bowie tunes, "Ziggy Stardust."As I was unable to attend Bowie's show here in Atlanta, I am grateful for this DVD, and not disappointed in it in the slightest.  The songs are terrific, the performances spot-on, the energy level of the audience is extremely high, and the song-list is nigh-perfect.If you already own the BEST OF BOWIE DVD, this makes a perfect complement to that.  An incredibly enjoyable show.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Of course there are many who aren't crazy about this DVD because of the bizarre editing and the overall presentation of it.  It doesn't play like your regular concert DVD (check out the bizarre fade to black and white during "Under Pressure"), but, when have we ever known David Bowie to do anything the standard way?  This is an artist who has made a career by bucking the trends and straying from the norm, so this DVD makes sense!Without question, this concert captures Bowie at the best he has sounded and looked (close-ups make one wonder if the Thin White Duke has had some cosmetic surgery!) in years!  Rather than do a straightforward "greatest hits" show like many of his contemporaries would, Bowie mixes a handful of hits with some new material, some deep cuts and some crowd favorites.Having seen this tour in New York City a few weeks after this performance, I was glad to see that the set-list was almost identical.  In fact, the only changes are that Bowie performs even more here!Bowie gives an intense and energetic performance all throughout and his backup band is stellar!  There are many moments to cherish, but for me the real highlights are the amazing performance of "Under Pressure," the always enjoyable "Five Years," and the moving "Slip Away," a more recent Bowie composition.There are many who were skeptic when Bowie announced that he was going to embark on his first stadium tour in years (bad memories of "The Glass Spider" tour are still etched in many peoples minds.)  But the "Reality" tour was a bonafide success and this DVD proves why Bowie remains one of the most versatile and important performers today.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Why do the folks who edit or direct these concert DVD's seem hellbent on giving us headaches with all the quick camera jumps and long angle shots and special effects that only take away from the enjoyment of the show?Ya know what? Bootleggers are doing it better these days, visually speaking, if only because they have no choice but to offer one, maybe two, and at the most, three angles and you get a much better feel for the experience because you're not all over the place and feeling like you're in a musical funhouse.I don't understand it.It's almost like the editor/director has to be as big a star as the artist.Just give us a good view of the stage and the band and let it go.The music speaks for itself, but the visuals make it hard to watch these things for more than ten minutes at a time.
summary: When will the directors get outta the way?
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm now watching the dvd for a second time.  It's power is just amazing.  The opening on Rebel Rebel is just awesome as well.I attended the April 30th concert at the Saengar Theatre, in New Orleans.  It brings back some great memories from that night.  Only a few differences...."WE"(New Orleans) got 31....yes....31 songs that night that lasted well over 2 1/2 hours.  I love the way the show was recorded, all the special effects.  Only one thing is missing that I've noticed, is when David talks with the crowd and jokes a bit.  He did that so much in New Orleans.  Only a few times on the dvd.  Not many.  The sound on the DVD is just excellant.  I love the lighting as well.I'll say though...as great as this DVD really is, and as much as I recommend this to ANY music fan.  That night in New Orleans was more than THE BEST ever!  I only pray that he returns next year.  He is amazing!For $10.49, how can one not buy a copy?  They don't come better priced than that!  It's worth triple that!
Title: N/A

reviewText: David Bowie is one person who really developed as a showman. I've never seen him give a half-hearted or unprepared performance, he is 100% professional. Yes, skills have been learned from the Ziggy Stardust days. This concert, even though I do not personally like all his new material is skillfully presented. However as some have commented the extra video trickery is totally unecessary and almost detract from the performance. When that is not there you get a real clean performance and feel you are part of the audience. A real good selection of musician's especially the bassist and the drummer both are incredibly talented and to Bowie's credit he allows them to shine. With Mike Garson on keyboards perhaps one of Bowie's long time associates who to me really adds some lovely keyboard expressions to the music that makes a studio song something new and different. Don't forget Bowie is also a gifted guitarist and it is nice to see him involved, but probably nit as much as I would like to see. Finally Earl Slick only now maturing as a guitarist and really adding to the performance. Even for Bowie performing so many concerts, to me he seems to enjoy the performance and wants to give his best. Don't hesitate buy this one.
summary: Live Concerts Can Be The Best Performance
Title: N/A

reviewText: This disc can be recommended for the stereo soundtrack alone. I noticed a few quirks with the 5.1 tracks, the sound will alternate between 5.0 and 4.0. The center channel output is inconsistent and there is no appreciable subwoofer bass (normal for music oriented discs). Otherwise a very good value and excellent video, looks like they used digital video instead of film. Picture is widescreen but am unsure if it is anamorphic for 16:9 sets.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have seen David Bowie in the past and he is fantastic live.  I was hoping the intenisty of seeing him in person would transfer over to the DVD.  I turned out the lights, cranked the music up and bought a six pack.The band was flawless and sounded great.  I would like to have seen some interaction between Bowie and the band.  Or at the very least to see the band move around and rock out, instead you get a great band that seems to know its place in the show.The concert started out great and I could feel the anticpation building.  I would have liked to see the set list build on the energy by throwing back to back hits.  It seemed for every song that I could sing along to the next song would be one that was less familar.My major complaint was the editing.  It got to be very artsy and would freeze frame than add color around Bowie and the band.  It was very psyhcadilic perhaps the editor anticpated viewers would be on something when they watched the video.  Also the angles and view points changed rapidly throw in the pulsating light and I felt a seizure could be a very real concern.The video sadly was not like being there, but all in all the music was great and you can never go wrong with Bowie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: One of the import versions of David Bowie's REALITY cd includes a bonus dvd disc of a concert from somewhere in Asia. The bonus dvd on that import is just a straightforward multicamera shoot, with no fancy special effects. And yet it is a thousand times better than this A REALITY TOUR dvd! Granted, the A REALITY TOUR has a more extensive set list, but the editing of this video - the processing of every minute of the video to make it look unreal - ruins the experience by distancing the viewer from the performance. One complaint about the performance is that I'd rather have seen Bowie have a full range of backup singers rather than employing whatever tricks were employed to flesh out the sound. That probably would not have seemed a problem if the rest of the video (the visual treatment) had been more honest. But altogether, it is as if the real show is hidden from the viewer.
Title: N/A
